name: Topics in Women's History
description: This course introduces students to the diverse experiences of women from a comparative perspective. Students will study how womens strategies have shaped the major cultural, economic, political and social processes in the world and how these processes have affected womens experiences in their particular societies. By studying womens history from both local and global perspectives, students will engage critically with claims that womens history is universal. The local focus of the course will rotate between Africa, Asia, Europe, and North America, depending on the expertise of the instructors.
